--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Philip Tucker" <tucker0171@y...> wrote:
> > --- Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> > > Normally I would resist placing extra data into an
> > > XML dialect that
> > > could be inferred from other data, it's effectibely
> > > redundant. However I
> > > understand it may be a pain to do complex logic in
> > > XSLT and as such I
> > > think it's reasonable to define, say, an attribute
> > > on neuron tags such
> > > as hintLayer="1".
> >
> > This is probably what we'll do then.
> >
> > In the next few days I'll upload a sample network (or
> > phenotype) XML file and the XSL style sheet that
> > parses it into an SVG graphic (into the NEAT XML
> > folder of the "Files" section of the Yahoo Group
> > page).  We can then hash out preferences/changes, etc.
> >
> > Derek
> 
> I like that idea.  Except, instead of "hintLayer", how about if we
make it
> something more explicit like "distance-from-input"; i.e., the
shortest path
> between that neuron and in the input layer?
> 
> Derek and I also talked about doing something more complex than
shortest
> path.  Every neuron is going to have (potentially) many many paths
of
> different lengths between it and the input and output layers, even
with
> recurrent connections disregarded.  If you use shortest distance,
all it
> takes is one connection to the input layer to "yank" that neuron
back to the
> first hidden layer, even though it may have many more connections
with
> longer paths that, overall, would more logically place it in a layer
closer
> to the output.
> 
> Also, if what we really want is something readable, even if the
network
> logically lays out as a 3 layer network with 2000 nodes in the
hidden layer,
> a layout that breaks that layer into multiple layers probably would
be more
> readable.
> 
> What if we calculated a ratio of average distance to the output and
input
> layers from each neuron?  For example, let's say a neuron has:
> 
> - several paths between it and the input layer whose average
distance is 3
> connections
> - several paths between it and the output layer whose average
distance is 2
> connections
> 
> It's "layer-placement-factor" (or whatever we want to call it) would
be 0.6;
> i.e., it should be placed in a layer about 3/5 of the way between
the input
> and output layers.  Then, whatever's doing the graphical layout can
sort all
> the neurons in ascending order of this factor and place them in
layers
> accordingly.
> 
> Maybe that's all overkill, but it seems like it would give whatever
utility
> is doing the layout the information it needs to determine layers
without
> forcing neurons into a specific layer.
> 
> - Philip

This is about the way I programmed my network graphing program.  You
also need to add a little bit a random noise to the horizontal
placements or else everything aligns and connections land on top of
each other.  But I think there might be better ways to do this...note
that that what you are proposing is very computationally intensive and
may not be tractable for large networks (although fine and neat
looking with small ones).

ken
